subject: Photography
title: Early Portrait Studios
description: A fast breakdown of Early Portrait Studios for builders.

hook.text: Before photography, only the wealthy could afford painted portraits. The camera changed that in a decade.

buildup.text: By the 1840s, portrait studios lined city streets. A sitting cost what a worker earned in a day.

discovery.text: Subjects had to sit still for thirty seconds or more. Clamps held heads in place to prevent blur.

twist.text: The results looked stiff and serious â€” not because people were unhappy, but because smiling for thirty seconds is hard.

climax.text: For the first time in history, ordinary families could see and keep an image of their own face.

punchline.text: They weren't sad. They were holding still.

quiz.question: Why do people in early photographs look so serious?
options: Long exposure times required them to stay perfectly still
